title: change health conditions lockdown twice
story: A NEW change in lockdown rules means people with certain health conditions can now leave home twice a day.It comes after a legal discussion between Public Health England and a firm representing two autistic children who need to leave twice for their health.Now those with health conditions which require them to leave home more than once a day will be allowed to do so.The updated guidance now reads: You can leave your home for medical need.If youhave a specic health condition that requires you to leave the home to maintain your health - includingthat involves travel beyond your local area - then you can do so.This could, for example, include where iniduals with learning disabilities or autism require specic exercise in an open space two or three times each day - ideally in line with a care plan agreed with a medical professional.Before the change Brits were only allowed to leave their homes once a day and not allowed to travel signicant distances.People are only allowed to leave their home for the following very limited purposes:It comes after Birdmans LLP law firm was asked to help by two families with children on the autistic spectrum.The firm explained: One child in particular is deliberately taken to a quiet location that is not local to them, because of their particular needs and where there is a far more limited risk of infectionthanhe were to remain in an urban environment.It was submitted that adults and children with certain health conditionswere disproportionately impacted by the inflexible policy which required everyone to only leave the house for exercise once per day, and which was therefore unlawful and discriminatory.After the change, a spokesperson for the Cabinet Office said: “The single most important action we can all take, in fighting coronavirus, is to stay at home in order to save lives, protect the vulnerable and protect the NHS.“We understand that this will be more dficult for some, that’s why we claried the guidance regarding the needs of those with specic health conditions such as learning disabilities or autism.It comes as police called for further lockdown powers.At least five chief constables support bans on long car journeys and outdoor exercise as they gear up for a sunny Easter weekend.They are urging ministers to give them the powers they need to keep lockdown enforced over Easter.People have been ignoring social distancing rules and flocking to parks and beaches across the country as the weather warms up.Health Secretary Matt Hancock warned last weekend restrictions would have to be tightened  people continued to ignore the lockdown.A Government evaluation of lockdown powers in England is considering tougher restrictions such as those in force in Wales - including restricting exercise to once a day.Before falling ill, Boris Johnson pledged to review the lockdown on Easter Monday, April  — three weeks after it began on March .But Downing Street is seriously concerned that people may defy advice and head out to enjoy the C bank holiday sunshine.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappeal

title: uk lockdown dominic raab too early
story: IT IS too early to lt the coronvirus lockdown measures right now and Brits must stay home this Easter bank holiday weekend, Dominic Raab said tonight.The Foreign Secretary, who is standing in for Boris while hes in hospital, apologised to the nation that they will be unable to see their families this weekend as part of the fight to stop the virus.And he took the chance to thank everyone - including NHS staff on the front line - for their hard work so far in savings lives.He told the public ahead of a sunny weekend: It is too early to lt the measures we have put in place.We must stick to the plan and continue to be guided by the science.Thank you for your sacrice but we are not done yet. We must keep going.No easing of the lockdown will happen until at least the end of next week, he said - but the strict measures will likely continue for even longer.Professor Chris Whitty said he would expect the number of deaths to continue rising for at least two weeks past when the number of people in intensive care starts to flatten off, showing the peak is still some time away.Mr Raab urged anyone considering breaking the rules in the coming days to think very hard about those who were on the front line battling the virus.He would usually be spending the Easter bank holiday weekend with his family but admitted we just cant do those sorts of things, and I am really sorry about that.As a country we need to be united in this mission.We have to keep it up.Mr Raab admitted tonight that he hasnt spoken to Boris Johnson since he went into hospital, and was rushed into intensive care on Monday evening.He said it was important to give him time to rest and recover, and stressed I’ve got all the authority I need to make the relevant decisions.That will include huge choices on extending the lockdown next week,the PM isnt well enough by then.The news came as:The Government is continuing to gather all the data on how the lockdown is working so far before making any firm calls, he said.The early signs suggest that they are having an impact, but its too early to say that conclusively, he added.We will be guided by the science at all times.We dont expect to be able to say more on this until the end of next week.The measures will have to stay in place until we have the evidence that clearly shows weve moved beyond the peak.Mr Raab said the PM was still in intensive care but continues to make positive steps forward, and he is in good spirits.He is still not in need of a ventilator and is able to breathe without assistance.Boris is said to be sitting up in bed and talking to the NHS staff who are caring for him too.It’s expected that the lockdown will be extended title: brits flout lockdown rules uk coronavirus
story: Others were spotted sunbathing topless and enjoying barbecues on the beach.It comes as forces across the UK are preparing to ramp up enforcement of coronavirus regulations with tomorrow set to be the hottest Good Friday ever.In a blatant breach of the lockdown rules, a group of teens were spotted inhaling balloons in Hampstead Heath, in North London, this afternoon.One onlooker told the Sun Online: They were in a group of around five or six. They were sat drinking from plastic bottles and inhaling balloons.They were clearly ignoring the lockdown rules.Brits were also snapped soaking up the sun on Brighton Beach today, while police ordered a couple to put out their barbecue.As the country heads into the Easter bank holiday weekend, No  said it is at a critical juncture in the battle to curb the spread of the deadly virus.The Prime Ministers official spokesman made clear there can be no early lting of the strict social distancing rules, urging the public to stick with it.Tourist hotspots have said holidaymakers and second homeowners are not welcome during the Easter weekend, as they urged visitors to stay at home.Northamptonshire Chief Constable Nick Adderley said his force was only a few days away from imposing road blocks and searching shopping trolleys for non-essential itemspeople continued to flout the rules.If things dont improve, and we dont get the compliance we would expect, then the next stage will be road blocks and it will be stopping people to ask why they are going, where theyre going, he said.This is about reasonableness andpeople are not reasonable in terms of the journeys and the trips they are taking, they are going to fall foul of the law.Cheshire police said there were plans for patrols on major roads, with officers stopping drivers to check whether their travel was essential, while Avon and Somerset said they would have more police on the roads.Meanwhile, Greater Manchester Police revealed they had to break up a staggering  parties last weekend – some with DJs, fireworks and bouncy castles.There were , coronavirus-related breaches reported between Saturday and Tuesday, the force said.The Government is due to carry out the first three-week review of the restrictions introduced last month early next week.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: inside worlds last cannibal tribes human flesh rituals
story: The tribes exist in some of the remotest corners of the world, and can be seen living as they have done for thousands of years.The Aghori monks of India use herbal drugs, alcohol, and meditation as well as human flesh in their rituals.The group reportedly obtain corpses from the Ganges River, downstream from where they are set afloat by relatives unable to afford a cremation or burial.In , US broadcast Reza Aslan met the a number of the monks and was filmed eating human brain while taking part in a ritual.Freelance photographer Tamara Merino, who also spent time with the group, said: “They are people that have so much love and respect for people, animals and nature.It’s just as beautul as any other religion is.”The Asmat people are native to New Guinea Island, and are thought to have traditionally hunted their enemies and used their skulls in cooking.Journalist Carl Hoffman wrote of the group: “They shook the brains out onto the leaf of a palm, scraped inside the skull with a kne to get every last bite, then mixed the mass with sago, wrapped the leaf up, and roasted it on the fire.The group is thought to have been responsible for the  death of Michael Rockefeller, a member of the Rockefeller dynasty and fth son of future vice president Nelson Rockefeller.Rockefeller was on an expedition in the New Guinea region when the boat in which he was travelling capsized.He left a companion drting with the boat and swam  miles to shore, but is thought to have been killed by the Asmat after he arrived.The Korowai are a tribe that live in West Papau in the western half of New Guinea Island.They live mostly in dense areas of rainforest, and remain isolated from much of modern world.Italian photojournalist Gianlunca Chiodini said of several days he spent with the group: “I really wanted to visit one of the most genuine and remote tribes in the world.“The Korowai live in the heart of the rainforest, where they’re not yet exposed to the modern world, so they still maintain many of their age-old traditions.”The group reportedly continue to practice witchcraft and to eat human flesh, though has been speculation that members have encouraged the stories to promote interest from the outside world.The Sentinelese are a tribe that live on North Sentinel, an island off the eastern coast of India, and are among the last truly uncontacted people in the world.They speak a unique language and have had very limited contact with the outside world.They have been described as a Stone Age tribe, and are believed to have lived on the island in isolation for up to , years.In , the group killed US missionary John Allen Chau with bows and arrows after he landed on the island as part of an attempt to convert its inhabitants to Christianity.Speaking at the time about planned attempt to recover Chaus body, Survival Internationals Director Stephen Corry said: The risk [to the Sentinelese] of a deadly epidemic of flu, measles, or other outside disease is very real, and increases with every contact.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: babies buggies breathe polluted air
story: Researchers simulated  school drop-off and pick-up trips — walking around . miles between am and am, and pm to pm.Three styles of buggy were used in Guildford, Surrey — single forward-facing and rear-­facing, and a two-tier type.They found that on average — regardless of the pushchair type — tots could be breathing  per cent more harmful pollutants than their parents.And with the double pushchair, the child at the bottom faced up to  per cent higher­ ­ex­posure to pollutants than the one in the top seat.The team from University of ­Surrey’s Global Centre for Clean Air Research found that pushchair covers reduced the concentration of small-sized pollutant par­ticles by as much as  per cent.Its Professor Prashant Kumar said: “For parents, nothing is more important than the health of our children.Covers and upping the buggy heights appears to have shielded children from an appreciable amount of pollution under certain conditions.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: louisiana dad disfigured burns pouring gasoline barbecue
story: Charles Dittler felt like he was burning alive during the accident, which left him in a medically induced coma for two weeks.The dad-of-one suffered third-degree burns to his face, arms and torso in the January  incident,reported.Charles, of Shevreport, Louisiana, told the news outlet: I was at my ex-girlfriend’s house with some friends and we were hanging out around a fire in the backyard.The fire was dying out and I had filled up a can of diesel earlier that day so wanted to use it to liven up the fire.But I picked up a can full of gas instead and I had no idea it was not diesel.He said there was no time to react once he starting pouring and recalled the gas blowing up in his hand, exploding, and pushing him to the ground.I started rolling around and screaming I’m on fire someone put me out! It felt like my body was burning from the inside.I thought I was going to die there and then. I was burning alive, Charles explained.His ex-girlfriends dad, Darry Wright, came to Charles rescue with a fire extinguisher.Charles, who happened to be wearing fire-retardant work pants, was on fire for approximately  seconds, according to .He saved my le and I owe him a lot, Charles said of Darry.Immediately after the accident, he was airlted to Ochsner Medical Centre, Louisiana.Charles had to undergo physiotherapy and  surgeries, including multiple skin grafts and reconstructive work.Doctors used skin from his thigh and shoulder to repair his eyelids and neck.The also reconstructed his chin with arteries and tissue from his arm.A GoFundMe, created two years ago to help with Charles rehab and personal bills, has since raised nearly ,.My brother’s physical appearance was changed forever that day, the fundraisers organizer, Brandon Edwards wrote.Despite his altered looks, Charles is proud of who hes become.I want to use my experience to give other people hope and to ask other people to accept who they are.In a way I am glad it happened because it means I can have a positive impact on other people and make a dference, Charles told .He now talks on a local radio station for Motivational Mondays and aspires to visit schools in the future to discuss fire safety.Charles has also designed Pain to Purpose T-shirts, which he sells online and recommends others to weartheyve experienced pain in the past.Do you have a story for The US Sun team Email us at exclusive@the-sun or call   .Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: hero medical workers smiling coronavirus ppe
story: The hospital staff hope that by showing their faces through photographs attached to their PPE they will reassure worried patients.Last week respiratory therapist Robertino Rodriguez geared up for his sht at Scripps Mercy Hospital in San Diego.However, in a bid to ease the nerves of coronavirus patients, the doctor decided to laminate a photo of himself onto his personal protective equipment so that people could see what he looks like smiling, despite his face being covered in real le.Rodriguez shared the photo of himself donned in his unorm on Instagram on Sunday.The caption read: “Yesterday I felt bad for my patients in ER when I would come in the room with my face covered in PPE.“A reassuring smile makes a big dference to a scared patient.So today I made a giant laminated badge for my PPE so my patients can see a reassuring and comforting smile.”The hero also told Huffpost: “One thing health care workers do to make our patients feel at ease is to reassure them with our smiles but now that we have to wear masks, we are unable to do this.“A smile goes a long way in comforting a scared patient ― bringing some brightness in these dark times.“People love seeing that you went that extra mile to show them that you care.As healthcare professionals, we came into this field because of our compassionate hearts. story: A PENSIONER resorted to eating out of the rubbish bin to survive after her only food supply was stolen from her doorstep during the coronavirus lockdown.The woman, named only as Elizabeth, , title: teacher five miles walking lunches coronavirus lockdown
story: A TEACHER has been hailed a hero for walking over five miles a day to deliver packed lunches to disadvantaged children during the coronavirus pandemic.Zane Powles has handed out  lunches every day since the schools closed due to the pandemic on March .During his daily  hour and  minute deliveries, the -year-old knocks on the door and leaves the parcel on the front step before waiting at a safe distance until the sandwich bag is picked up.Zane, who works at Western primary school in Grimsby, Lincolnshire, said: Its about making sure vulnerable kids get at least one decent meal.People are risking their lives on the front line or delivering medicines as a volunteer, and Im doing this because its the right thing to do to help where I can.Its important that Im doing my bit in the national effort — as we go through this crisis as a country together.Hand-delivering the lunches is a better way than parents coming into the school as its all about reducing the risk of the virus spreading.Zane, who lives alone and has three sons, Jai , Bailey,  and Emil, , prefers to deliver them on foot rather than using his bike or car and enjoys the interaction he has with parents on his way.He added: It wouldnt be worthwhile using the car or bike and this way I meet people as Im doing it.When it became common knowledge a week ago people started coming out of their houses — congratulating me as I was doing my deliveries.But given its the new normal, everyone is doing their bit and delivering lunches to the most vulnerable is my contribution.Whenever they see me, parents and kids will come to the door.Most of them have been fantastic in following the advice to stay in doors and to stay two metres apart so they dont spread the virus.Executive head Kim Leach helps deliver the  remaining lunches along with teaching staff to kids who live further away.Praising Zane for his efforts, Kim said: We are very proud — he is a superstar and is a credit to the school and title: debenhams uk store closures latest
story: Read on to find out which branches are set to close, and why.Debenhams is shutting  of its stores this month, as it continues its massive programme of shop closures.At the end of , it was revealed that Debenhams was set to close  of its stores.But  stores have been confirmed to shut in the next three weeks, including Altrincham, Wolverhampton, Ashford and Wimbledon.Heres the full list title: pressure to end coronavirus lockdown
story: Ministers are reluctant to lt the strict measures despite experts claiming that Brits “cannot hide away forever”.Dominic Raab – filling in for Boris Johnson - warned yesterday it was still too early for social distancing to be lted.And epidemiologist Professor Neil Ferguson, of Imperial College London, said “definitive” proof of whether the nationwide-lockdown has worked will take “several more weeks”.He explained: “It is only when we see the case numbers come down and how quickly transmissions have been reduced we can really conclude anything about what happens next, when these measures can be relaxed”.It is believed that less than  per cent of the population has had the virus and Mr Raab said that discussing a route out of lockdown would be a “distraction”.Scientists are still struggling to identy how restrictions could be eased without causing more harm to the public, the Times reports.But Rupert Shute, the deputy scientic adviser at the Home Office, warned yesterday that  per cent of the population will eventually get Covid-.He added said that while staying at home was important “we also have to keep ing our lives”.Mr Shute told the BBC: “You are no more at risk at the workplace than you would be in your home or at the supermarket. It is about minimising it.“We are working on the assessment that  per cent of us,we haven’t already, will get the virus. We cannot hide away from it for ever.”He made the comments during a conference call with officials at the Passport Office – but a transcript was then handed to the BBCThe government has announced it was launching a publicity drive over the bank holiday weekend to get the public to follow the lockdown guidelines over East weekend.Concerning figures show the number of hospital patients in the UK who had died after testing positive for Covid- had risen to , as of pm on Wednesday - an increase of  on the previous day.At the daily No  press conference, Mr Raab acknowledged that it was hard for to stay indoors over Easter, but he urged them to show restraint amid signs the measures were having an impact.He said: The deaths are still rising and we havent yet reached the peak of the virus. So its still too early to lt the measures that we put in place.We must stick to the plan and we must continue to be guided by the science.Sir Patrick Vallance, the Governments chief scientic adviser, said measures were breaking transmission of the disease with signs of a flattening off in the numbers of new cases and hospital admissions.However, he warned the numbers of deaths would continue to rise for a few weeks and that it was too soon to relax social-distancing.It is incredibly important that we continue to do what we are doing, he said.The chief medical officer, Professor Chris Whitty, said that while the numbers admitted to intensive care had been doubling every three days, that had now slowed.This is really now becoming not quite flat, but the doubling time is now six or more days in almost everywhere in the country and extending in time, he said.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappeal

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe coronavirus is predicted to infect % of the UKaposs population, a government advisor has reportedly claimed. Rupert Shute, the deputy scientic adviser at the Home Office, has been slammed for the statement which was allegedly used to justy sending staff back to work. According to the BBC, he made the statement during a conference call with the Passport Office on Thursday over workers being asked to go back. In a leaked transcript of a Zoom meeting involving Passport Office managers, seen by the BBC, Mr Shute said: You are no more at risk at the workplace as you would be in your home or at the supermarket. It is about minimising it. We are working on the assessment that  per cent of us,we haven’t already, will get the virus. For the latest on the coronavirus pandemic, click here  We cannot hide away from it forever. Unions accused his wider comments of going against government guidelines. The Prime Ministeraposs spokesman said yesterday: The government’s view is on stopping the spread of the disease to save lives. The governmentaposs top scientic advisors did originally say the virus might infect up to % of the population. But those estimates were made before strict lockdown measures were brought in to reduce the rate of infection and number of people ill. The lockdown was introduced amid widespread concern about the impact of aposherd immunityapos after government advisors realised the strategy of only slowing the spread of Covid-, and not trying to suppress it completely, could lead to , deaths. Mark Serwotka, general secretary of the PCS Union said: “It is absolutely scandalous that HMPO are suggesting our members can go back into work during a pandemic to process routine passports. The cavalier approach to our membersapos health and safety is shameful and ultimately puts them in greater danger of contracting Covid-. A Home Office spokesman said: Her Majestyaposs Passport Office is fully adhering to public health advice across all our offices and adopting social distancing measures to keep both its staff and customers safe. It continues to operate at substantially restricted staffing levels with a signicant number of people working from home where possible, and staff are prioritising emergency cases. Guidance is also available for people who are travelling into work. It was made clear in the meeting that the Governmentaposs priority is slowing the spread of coronavirus and we all have a part to play in order to protect the NHS and save lives. Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab, who is standing in for Prime Minister Boris Johnson while he recovers from the virus, told Brits the dramatic lockdown measures would stay in place until there is strong evidence that it is working. In the daily press conference yesterday he said: We are not done yet, we must keep going.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailUK health chiefs are considering the idea of freeing younger people from coronavirus lockdown earlier than the elderly, Public Health Englandaposs Medical Director said today. Experts at Warwick University floated the idea this week - which could include reopening schools - because young people face a comparatively lower risk from Covid . Warwickaposs briefing paper, The case for releasing the young from lockdown, suggested releasing those aged - who do not live with older citizens, as the best approach to eventually lting the lockdown. Data suggested it could allow . million young adults to resume their daily lives, and shield society against an economic collapse. Medics and government ministers have made clear the lockdown will not be lted in any way for at least a few weeks, despite a review next week, and have urged people to focus on sticking to the rules. However, ministers are also facing questions about what the exit strategy will eventually be once the number of coronavirus infections starts to drop. Prof Paul Cosford, Emeritus Medical Director of Public Health England, today said releasing younger people earlier than others is being looked at. Asked directly about the idea, he told BBC Radio aposs Today programme: All those are sort of things that will need to be considered and are being considered. Medics have stressed that, while the risk of complications is far higher in the elderly, anyone of any age can fall seriously ill and die from Covid-. Prof Cosford said closing schools was an “important measure” to stop the spread of the virus, but said that despite some tragic cases, children are “at very low risk of getting serious complications”.  He added: “The importance of children’s eduction and children being in school is paramount. “That’s not the only issue, but I could conceive of circumstances in which some of the restrictions are lted sooner and some are lted later.” Asked directlyschools could open in a first wave of easing restrictions, he said: “Maybe. Some countries are looking at that. Other countries are looking at dferent ways of doing this.”  However, Prof Cosford also warned we have an “awfully long way to go” before any restrictions are lted at all, and “several weeks isn’t unreasonable. Let’s hope it’s sooner than that.” Ministers have also refused to be drawn on when schools could reopen, with few expecting them to open their doors after the Easter break and Scotlandaposs Nicola Sturgeon predicting they wonapost. All my experience dealing with any sort of infectious disease suggests once you start getting things under control, that is the time you absolutely need to continue with all your measures so you can bring the disease right down, essentially to crack it across the country, Prof Cosford said.  Professor Stephen Powis, the National Medical Director of NHS England, also suggested the idea was under consideration. Askedrestrictions could be lted by age and geography, he told Sky News today: “Those discussions are still taking place. There are lots of options being looked at.” But just like Public Health England, Prof Powis emphasised we shouldnapost expect any measures to be lted any time soon - and must follow the rules. He added: “This is not something that any country will be able to manage in a matter of weeks. We are going to have to work out a strategy and approach to managing this virus over months.”  It comes as Brits are urged to heed warnings that they should stay at home over the warm Easter weekend. There were encouraging signs on Thursday that the public were largely following the strict guidelines, with traffic levels showing an absence of a mass weekend getaway. The government has launched a publicity drive urging people to stay in their homes - including Easter eggs foil-wrapped with the words STAY HOME, SAVE LIVES.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe UKaposs coronavirus lockdown looks set to be extended as Brits hunker down for the long haul. Drastic limits on leaving your home will be reviewed by April  - but itaposs clear they wonapost be lted. As coronavirus deaths continue to rocket, they will probably drt on into May at least. A meeting of the COBRA emergency committee today kicked off the process of working out what to do next, chaired by Boris Johnsonaposs deputy Dominic Raab. But the government isnapost planning to actually tighten the law - yet. Instead the focus will be on enforcing the law we already have and making it last longer.  Meanwhile police are preparing for a tough Easter weekend - with threats to search peopleaposs shopping and fine anyone going to bask in the sun. So what can and canapost you do under the lockdown law, what is changing, and when will it all end   Hereaposs the lockdown latest explained. What are the basic lockdown rules  You cannot leave the house where you live without reasonable excuse. That boils down to:Shopping for basic necessities, for example food and medicine, which must be as infrequent as possible One form of exercise a day, for example a run, walk, or cycle - alone or with members of your household Any medical need, including to donate blood, avoid or escape risk of injury or harm, or to provide care or to help a vulnerable person Travelling for work purposes, but only where you cannot work from home. Gatherings of more than two people are banned in public - unless youaposre from the same household, or a few other exceptions . And pubs, cafes, restaurants, gyms, funfairs, playgrounds, sports courts, cinemas, theatres, nightclubs, bingo halls, concert halls, museums, galleries, car showrooms, casinos, betting shops, spas, hair and beauty salons, barbers, massage parlours, tattoo studios, skating rinks and more must shut.  What is the punishment for breaking the lockdown  Breaking the rules above without reasonable excuse, or obstructing an officer enforcing them, is a criminal offence and you can be prosecuted. However, you can in most cases avoid a criminal conviction by paying a aposfixed penalty noticeapos issued by the police within  days. The law allows police to issue £ fixed penalty notices - rising to £ for a second offence and then doubling each time up to a cap of £. Police, PCSOs, council officers and other government representatives can also order or force you toto your home, and disperse gatherings of more than two people.  When did the UK go into lockdown - and for how long  The lockdown was announced by Prime Minister Boris Johnson on Monday  March. It took effect immediately. Police powers to enforce the lockdown took force a few days later - at pm on Thursday  March. The law says the lockdown must be reviewed by Health Secretary Matt Hancock every three weeks, with the first review by Thursday  April. But reviewing the lockdown doesnapost mean it stops. The law is in force for up to six months without the government needing to write a new one. Will the lockdown be extended for longer than three weeks  Yes. The UK government hasnapost made an official announcement because thataposll only come next week. But ministers, civil servants and  Downing Street have been absolutely clear that April  is much too soon to end the lockdown. Wales has already confirmed it will extend the lockdown. Scotlandaposs First Minister Nicola Sturgeon added: I don’t think there is any possibility, any likelihood of these lockdown measures being lted immediately or even imminently. Even before a COBRA meeting to discuss the lockdown, Downing Street basically confirmed the UK government agrees with Ms Sturgeon.  Why isnapost the extension being announced properly today  Because the government wants to wait to see how well the restrictions are working at reducing cases. A formal announcement will be made on or before April , based on scientic evidence. Whoaposll make the decision  Technically itaposs made by Health Secretary Matt Hancock but itaposll be overseen by Boris Johnsonaposs stand-in, Dominic Raab. Not the PM, whoaposs in intensive care. Downing Street said: The Prime Minister is not working. I think weaposre very clear on that. And he has asked the First Secretary of State to deputise for him. It will be the First Secretary of State who leads the COBRA meeting [on Thursday] and the First Secretary of State who will lead any cabinet decision making process.  So can I go out for a picnic this Easter weekend then  No, absolutely not. Yes, the lockdown is being reviewed, but that absolutely does not mean it has stopped. You may only go outside your home with a reasonable excuse - just like any other day under lockdown. When will the lockdown end  We donapost know. But it will only be lted when the UK is well over the peak of new Covid- cases per day, and thataposs not any time soon. Ministers had hoped the peak would be Easter Sunday but estimates now put it at least a week or two later. Even then, cases have to drastically dwindle too. Otherwise thereaposll just be a second outbreak. The UK government has also repeatedly refused to say what its aposexitapos strategy is. Until we get a vaccine next year, itaposs quite possible they just donapost know yet. Officials havenapost ruled out a partial end to the lockdown, where some people can go outside earlier than others. Or restrictions being lted for a few weeks, then reimposed.  Are even stricter restrictions on the way  Not right now, no. The government hasnapost ruled out making the rules even stricter - such as banning exercise. But No emphasised the focus is on policing the current rules more strictly, not making new ones. Boris Johnsonaposs spokesman said: I think the focus for now is ensuring that people continue to stick by the measures weaposve put in place. Culture Secretary Oliver Dowden warned the government may enhance or change the lockdown, but thataposs not happening right now. No said: Weaposve always said thatthe scientic advice suggested other steps are needed weaposd be prepared to take them. But for now our focus is on ensuring the steps we already have in place are properly enforced. What does the law actually say  The lockdown is enforced through a law called the Health Protection Regulations . Importantly, it isnapost exactly the same as the government guidance. You should of course follow both, but it makes a dference to whether police can stop you going about your business. Here we go through a few common situations. Whataposs the full list of aposreasonable excusesapos for leaving my house  Reasonable excuses include, but it appears are not limited to:To obtain basic necessities, including food and medical supplies for those in the same householdor for vulnerable persons To take exercise either alone or with other members of their household To seek medical assistance To provide care or assistance to a vulnerable person, or to provide emergency assistance To donate blood To travel for the purposes of work or to provide voluntary or charitable services, where it is not reasonably possible for that person to work from home To attend a funeral of a member of the person’s household, a close family member, orneither are attending, a friend To fulfil a legal obligation, including attending court or satisfying bail conditions To access critical public services, including childcare school, social services, DWP services, victims of crime services To allow children with shared custody to move between each parentaposs house For a minister of religion, to go to their place of worship To move house where reasonably necessary To avoid injury or illness or to escape a risk of harm.When can more than two people gather in public  Exceptions to the rule are:Where all the people in the gathering are members of the same household Where the gathering is essential for work purposes To attend a funeral To facilitate a house move* To provide emergency assistance* To fulfil a legal obligation* To provide care to a vulnerable person** Where reasonably necessary. Can police fine meI exercise twice in one day  No. Government guidance is clear - you should only exercise once a day. You should follow this advice. But the law itself doesnapost specy how many times you can go out. It just says you may take exerciseyou need to. Meanwhile, guidance has been updated to let people with a medical need go out multiple times a day, for instance people with learning disabilities or autism.  Can police stop me sitting in the park  Yes,you canapost provide a reasonable excuse. You wonapost be surprised to hear the list of possible reasonable excuses does not include sitting, having a picnic or sunbathing - evenyouaposre doing it with proper social distancing. Police have of course been asked to show discretion, and there are exceptions in the rules for people with a medical need. Can police go through my shopping  The law isnapost % clear - but the Home Secretary has said itaposs not appropriate. It comes after a police force threatened to go through peopleaposs bags to check for non-essential items. After an outcry, Northamptonshire Police later claried: We absolutely will NOT be searching peopleaposs shopping trolleys in Northamptonshire. Home Secretary Priti Patel later said this is not appropriate and branded it heavy-handed. So thataposs all good. But what does the law say  The law says you can go out to buy basic necessities, including food and medical supplies. So you might interpret that asyou start buying non-essential items, youaposre breaking the law. But the government also says open shops donapost have to pull all their non-essential items from stock. So Sainsburyaposs can carry on selling, say, kidsapos toys and paddling pools - and thereaposs nothing to stop you buying them. Shops that are still open are free to sell any items that they have in stock, Downing Street told us. Yet Downing Street also told us: When we ask the police to carry out enforcement of any rules we give them discretion on how to do that. Thataposs the nature of policing in the UK. They have set out in guidance to officers that they should engage, explain, encourage and then finally enforce.

story: NewsopinionVoice of the Mirror: Coronavirus and lack of PPE has turned care homes into death trapsThe battle against the Covid- pandemic in the UK is not just being fought in our hospitals and surgeriesShareByVoice of the Mirror:,  APR NewsopinionSeven residents of Hawthorn Green home in Stepney - which houses  people - have died since the pandemic started " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe priority in fighting the coronavirus has been to make sure the NHS has the equipment and resources it needs. Everyone understands the importance of supporting doctors, nurses and other staff on the frontline. That is why you came out in your millions again last night to applaud our  brilliant national health service. But the battle against the pandemic is not just being fought in our hospitals and surgeries. In the scramble to shore up the NHS, the Government appears to have neglected the half a million people in care homes. These residents are almost exclusively in the high-risk category. Yet care home operators say they have been ignored and are struggling to get the help they need. Many are short of staff because workers have had to go into self-isolation. Others desperately want personal protection equipment such as face masks and gloves. One home in Luton has reported that  of its residents have died and tragically there are more cases emerging across the country. Without urgent action more lives will be lost. We cannot allow these homes, offering comfort and support, to turn into death traps. Break traditionThe Easter break is traditionally a time for worship and for friends and familiesto come together.A time when children enjoy Easter Egg hunts and many head for the country or coast. With good weather in many parts, the temptation to break the lockdown restrictions will be strong. But we urge you to stay home.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email A mum has given a harrowing account of the final visit she and her children made to their dad as he lies dying in hospital with coronavirus. Cardf mum Sue Martin spoke to the BBCaposs Today programme about the fateful call from doctors telling her that her husband was being put on a ventilator, and the shell-shocked family needed to say goodbye.Sue described her -year-old husband Mal Martin as fit and healthy. But the devastated family has been told he has aposzero chanceapos of survival. The mum gave an emotional interview recounting the familyaposs final phone call, and a ten-minute visit behind screens around Malaposs hospital bed. Her description of the moment she and the coupleaposs two children, aged  and , stood behind screens around a sleeping Malaposs bedside to say their goodbyes moved listeners to tears. The family was allowed to go into hospital in full protective wear for what is likely to be the last time they are all together. Malaposs we and children could not even touch him to say farewell as they stood around his bedside at the Princess of Wales Hospital in Bridgend. Sue recalled: We just told him that we loved him. It was heartbreaking to hear the children tell him that they were going to make him proud. The family have been left to prepare for the beloved husband and fatheraposs death as he lies in intensive care on the brink of organ failure. Despite being told there was no way he would pull through, Sue says the family is living in hope of a miracle.According to the Independent, Mal is chairman of a recruitment firm and Sue is a communications manager at the Department for Transport, and the couple have been together for  years.Mal has Type  diabetes and had suffered a heart attack four years ago, but had lived a very, very healthy le, his we told the Today programme.   Sue said Mal first began feeling unwell with cold-like symptoms on March , and his condition got progressively worse. After about a week, his condition declined so badly he could not get out of bed. Sue told the Independent Mal had a persistent cough, a headache and a temperature of .C. She added in the BBC interview: The cough was the worse thing for him. It was like nothing  Iaposve heard before. aposI wish we had been able to give him a hugapos Mal began self-isolating to keep the rest of his family safe as soon as he began feeling unwell. But when his condition did not improve after another week, Sue said she tried to seek medical advice. However she claimed she struggled to get through on attempts to call NHS  services, saying she kept being put on hold for more than an hour each time then was cut off. She then rang a doctor at the local surgery, who encouraged her to keep a record of Malaposs symptoms and check on him every second hour throughout the days.  But Malaposs symptoms went into sharp decline on March  and Sue said she stayed up all night anxiously checking his condition. At this stage his breathing rate was normal, and the doctor seemed satisfied by his condition and recommended he stay at home at that point. By the early hours of Sunday morning, ten days after he first began showing symptoms of coronavirus his condition was so poor, Sue called an ambulance. She described how his breathing had become rapid, and when the paramedics arrived she and the children were not allowed to go near him. As he was rushed to hospital, they had to say their goodbyes there and then, Sue recalled. She said: It was awful because I wish now that we had been able to give him a hug. She did not know that the worst was yet to come, explaining that the family believed once Mal was admitted to hospital his condition would improve. Sue said: I really thought that a couple of days on oxygen and heaposd be back home with us.  But within around an hour of Malaposs arrival at hospital, she received a call from the AE at the Princess of AE Hospital saying he had whisked straight to intensive careand put on a ventilator. Sue said a doctor told her Mal was very, very sick and the family needed to be prepared that he might not pull through. Sue told Today she never thought her husband would be among the patients fighting for their lives in hospital. She described being shocked to hear that he may not survive, after he had been able to walk out of the family home to a waiting ambulance.  Sue recalled: The nurse said that she had spoken to him and he was aware of what was going to happen to him, and that they were going to put him to sleep and put him on a ventilator to do the breathing for him because his body was very tired and extremely poorly. The last time the family saw each other Sue was surprised to learn that he would soon be unconscious, saying I think I just assumed that a ventilator was like another type of oxygen mask, I didnapost realise it involved him being put to sleep. The nurse told her that Mal had asked for her to call him as he was too upset after he was told he may not ever come off the ventilator. Sue and her children called him over FaceTime, where they saw him struggling to breathe and already wearing an oxygen mask. The family were in tears, realising this might be the last time they were all together again as they were forced to say their goodbyes to Mal.  Sue said: We just told him how much we loved him and I said how much I was really sorry that I hadnapost sent him in earlier... They said in hospital that Iaposd done everything that I could have. He promised he would fight it. She said her husband promised their children he would pull through and be there for him.  He said to my daughter who was , Donapost worry, Iaposm going to be around a while yet and be here for your wedding and for you both growing up and see William play rugby for Wales - heaposs . He was told thathe did recover it would take over a year. Mal texted the family, promising he wouldnapost leave them, Sue said. He said it wasnapost his time, that he missed me too much and that he was coming home. When the text messages ceased, they knew it was because he had been put on the ventilator in ICU. Saying goodbye through a hospital screen She said: That day really was when everything changed for us and we have just been existing since.  She said the hospital had been amazing, with a consultant ringing every day with an update. At first the doctors told the family Mal had   chance of survival. But the -year-old dad is strong, fit and healthy, Sue said. She said the family kept faith when doctors said they would do everything they could to help him. But after a few days on the ventilator, the doctors told her despite their best efforts they had been unable to take him off the ventilator. Then Malaposs kidneys failed, and he was put on dialysis. After that, Sue received the fateful call from the doctors informing the family there was aposalmost zero chanceapos Mal would survive. The doctors told her they were giving him the maximum adrenaline they could to keep the blood pumping to his vital organs. But he was on the brink, and they told Sue they didnapost think they could do anything more for him as it was likely his organs begin failing. Reeling from the news, she rang the hospital again and begged to be able to see her husband. A nurse told Suethe family could get to the hospital quickly, they could have  minutes with Mal and even stayed two hours after her sht to ensure they fulfilled their desperate wish. The nursing sister helped the family dress in full personal protective equipment . Sue said they were taken in to say goodbye to Mal: we werenapost allowed to touch him, but we could speak to him. Essentially we were going in to say our goodbyes. I said to the children... aposyou absolutely donapost have to do this, this is a personal choice, thereaposs no right or wrong. You have to do what you feel.apos But they both wanted very much to come and see him. because they hadnapost been able to really hug him before he left. The family were forced to say their final goodbyes to Mal through screens around his bed. Sue said the medics were wonderful and compassionate.  She recounted the awful scene as she and her children stood around his hospital bed, unable to touch him. It was just like he was asleep. he had so many tubes and obviously wires in him and everything - it was like he was fast asleep. We just told him really that we love him, and it was heartbreaking, really, to hear the childrenthey were going to make him proud. She added: It was very hard not being able to touch him but we were glad to get to see him. aposA little glimmer of hopeapos The family had expected he would not survive Monday, but have since been told his condition has been improved slightly.Doctors said Malaposs lungs and kidneys had failed, but they had noted a slight increase in his blood pressure and were able to reduce his adrenaline .Sue said the family had accepted this did not mean he would survive. She said there had been no improvement or deterioration by Wednesday. He is still extremely, desperately ill and thereaposs still almost zero chance of him pulling through. As the emotional interview came to a close, Sue said the family had not yet given up hope. Although everyday we prepare for the worst, thereaposs a little glimmer of just maybe, just maybe, he might turn a corner. Chances of survival after ventilation slim The latest report into patients admitted into critical care in the UK showed that of those who required ventilation so far, just under a third have survived. Figures for England, Wales and Northern Ireland, from the intensive care national audit , showed that as at Friday, April , of , patients for whom data was available,  had died.  Another  patients were discharged alive from critical care and , patients were last reported as still being in critical care. The NHS requires an estimated , ventilators to meet the demand predicted for the peak of the Covid- pandemic in the UK.

title: chris packhams wildlife lockdown animal
story: NewsChris Packhams wildle lockdown: Animal magic with Britains springtime mammalsChris Packham continues his wildle lockdown series, with zoologist Megan McCubbin, and tells us about British mammals to keep your eyes peeled for in April and MayShareCommentsByRhian Lubin:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsChris Packham tells us about mammals to watch out for in Spring " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailWe might be in lockdown, but nature is doing the opposite at this time of year. Now is the time we can start to see mammals and their newborns pop their heads above ground. Today Chris Packham and zoologist Megan McCubbin talk about their favourite British mammals to keep your eyes peeled for in April and May. Badgers  Badgers are active throughout the course of the year and would’ve given birth in February or March, so in the next couple of weeks the young might be coming above ground for the first time. But they’ve very shy. They live in setts in the middle of the large territory that belongs to the whole family. The main sett is where the badgers live for most of the year and where they rear their babies but they also have smaller setts which they use in the Spring, Summer and Autumn so they can sleep near to where they find food.  A family of badgers can have a really big territory - each badger terrirtory might have up to six smaller setts. They’re sociable animals and like living with each other and love to play. And they’re really good at knowing which territory is theirs by their latrines - badgers have really distinct smelling faeces which they put at the edge of their territories so other families know they shouldn’t enter. It’s quite a sophisticated set up and is essential to their survival. Bats  We have  species of bat in the UK,  of which are known to be breeding here - that’s almost a quarter of our mammal species. They’re emerging this time of year and you can see them in all areas - urban or rural. But bats are always betteryou’ve got water near you. Soyou’re near a pond, reservoir, anything like that, you’ll see they’re beginning to emerge regularly. Bat populations have suffered severe declines during the past century. Deer  We had a muntjac deer near us the other day. You can tell the dference between male and female because the males have two very distinctive dark lines down the forehead and have very short antlers. The females are slightly paler. Muntjac have these amazing curved bottoms like rabbits. They are quite pig like with very sticky legs and are one of my favourites. They’re not native to the UK and were brought here in  to Woburn Safari Park. Some of them escaped, which is why they’re quite common across woodlands in the south of England. They’re very shy and secretive animals, soyou get a glimpse make the most of it. They’re fascinating, you can see them on roadsides nibbling at the verges. But they aren’t too popular with gardeners because they go for all the tasty parts of your plants - they love rosebuds. Also just be waryyou’re out walking your dog in an area where they might be and keep your animal on a lead. Foxes  April is the time we would expect start to see our fox cubs and they start to move around out of their den. If people are lucky enough to have a den in their garden shed, this is when they’ll first see the fox cubs. They’re very unfoxy when you first see them, they have quite blunt faces with short ears. They look quite cat-like, like kittens the nose hasn’t grown down yet and they’re chocolate brown in colour, they’re not red yet. Wobbling about with their skinny tails, they try to find their balance. We’ve already had reports of that cubs have been sighted as early as Christmas and January. This is really early, which is a sign of climate change. Fellow Springwatch presenter, Iolo Williams, told me he saw very young fox cubs and that was just before or after Christmas. That’s quite unusual. Otters  Pre s, where a lot of chemicals were put into our waterways, many of them were devoid of le and it damaged the eco systems. Everything at the top of the food chain disappeared. Otters only really occurred on the western side of the UK, in Wales, Cornwall and Devon. When I was a kid in the s, otters were a rather rare animal they were dficult to see and it didn’t occur in Hampshire where I grew up. Now they have recovered their range and have been found in every UK county, all the way across from the west and now including Kent. But they have not recovered their numbers, so there’s still scope for more otters to exist in our environment, particularly now our waterways have been cleaned up. We can’t be complacent about otter conservation just because they’re back everywhere - they’re not back in numbers they were, but it’s great to see them turning up. In urban areas they have even been turning up and you can see them in daytime from footpaths. Otters were almost an enigma and now are mostly accessible. The Sainsbury’s supermarket in Andover has a path that runs alongside the river and while you’re pushing your trolley you can look over the side and see them. How to make a hedgehog house and highway  Hedgehogs are a favourite this time of year - everyone loves hedgehogs. It’s mild and now’s the time they’re coming out into the garden soyou have a trap camera, now is the time to set it up. You can also make a little hedgehog house which is really simple. Get a bucket, put some hay or straw, grass, any long organic matter, inside the bucket, just something the hedgehog can hide in. Lie the bucket on its side and keep it steady with something so it doesn’t roll. Put it under a hedge or somewhere not exposed – they’re very secretive and shy things and are much more comfortable when they feel secure.

story: NewsDouble-lung transplantee has list of goodbye calls in case she gets coronavirusEXCLUSIVE: Justine Laymond, from Rayleigh, Essex, says she knows it will be "game over" for hershe gets coronavirus and is urging anyone thinking of breaking the lockdown to stay at homeShareCommentsByKelly-Ann Mills:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsJustine says she knowsshe catches covid- it could be the end for her " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA double-lung transplantee who knows she will dieshe catches coronavirus has written a list of people sheaposll call to say goodbye to,an ambulance is called. Justine Laymond has a permanently compromised immune system following her le-saving transplant back in  and has one of the worldaposs rarest lung diseases. Speaking to , the -year-old said she knows that catching Covid- would be game over for her, but she is determined to do all she can to stay safe at home. And she is calling on everyone across the UK to do their bit this weekend and asks anyone thinking of breaking the lockdown to simply not do it. She said: The sun may be shining outside - but darkness will fall on others who may die,not yourself. This is not a movie, itaposs reality. Have you got a coronavirus story  Email webnews@mirror Justine was just hours from dying back in July  when she fought back from being in a three-week coma, spending weeks on le support and  lung collapses to be well enough to be put on the transplant list. Her le was eventually saved when she received the healthy lungs of a -year-old man, and she was given another chance at le. But Justine, who is currently furloughed from her part time job at Hyundai in Chelmsford, admits she is frightened for her health once again. But after spending two days crying over what the deadly virus could mean for her, Justine picked herself up and decided to fight for her le - by staying safe and self-isolating. She said: Iaposm so frightened. Iaposm not going out to exercise every day. I need to keep my fitness up so my lungs stay healthy. But I knowI do get it, I will die. I would fight for my leI did get it, but I know it will kill me. Justine, from Rayleigh, Essex added: Iaposve got my wishes written out. If we have to call an ambulance, Iaposve got a list of people to call to say goodbye to. Iaposve got an emergency bag packed. I knowI get this I will die, thataposs the reality.  Justine, who is self-isolating with partner Tom Hipperson, was left in shock when she was not included in the Governmentaposs list of .milllion people most at risk from the virus. Despite being a transplantee, permanently immuno-compromised and having serious underlying health conditions, she did not get a text to say she would have help getting the vital medicines she takes each day, or have any way of getting food. After numerous calls to her GP and hospital, she was eventually told her medical records were not accurate and her medical code needed amending so she could be included on the high risk list.  And now she is back to her positive self, doing fitness classes at home and keeping up her hobbies as a drag queen, where she has a large online presence, and keeping busy with cos-play make up and art. She said: I know Iaposm in lockdown for  weeks, so you just have to change your mindset.

The victim, named locally as -year-old Ralph Baxter, collapsed and died at his home just  yards from the scene in the village of Roade near Northampton. A post-mortem examination at Leicester Royal Infirmary came back as “un-ascertained”. As a result a -year-old man who was arrested and who also lives in Roade was released on police bail to an address outside of Northamptonshire pending further enquiries. Mr Baxter had been awarded an MBE and was a retired civil servant who had worked for the Department of Work and Pensions. He had been walking his Shih Tzu Bertie at the start of a bridle way in Roade near Northampton on Wednesday afternoon when it was allegedly attacked by a large Husky. There was an angry confrontation between two men. Mr Baxter, a former Labour party agent and trade union leader, made it to his semi-detached home where he died. He collapsed in his front room with his we Anne nearby. After the incident he came home and told Anne, aposI’ve been attacked, I don’t feel goodapos, a neighbour told Mail Online.  Anne was making the dinner in the kitchen but by the time she had switched off the cooker and gone in to see him, he had collapsed. It is a tragedy. He was such a lovely man who saw it as his duty to help whoever he could. Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab, standing in for the Prime Minister, urged restraint amid signs social-distancing was beginning to work.But with temperatures set to soar over the bank holiday, police warned they were ready to take action against those who flout the rules. One police chief even warned his force was only “a few days away” from imposing roadblocks. The Devon  Cornwall force also said it would be patrolling the M motorway on the Somerset and Devon border to keep tourists away from the area.Military Defence Police, based in Portsmouth and Plymouth, will be operating along the coastlines in Dorset, Devon and Cornall to ensure people aposdo not gather unnecessarilyapos, reported i news on Thursday evening. It comes as Boris Johnson was last night moved back to the ward at St Thomas’ Hospital in South London after his condition improved following three anxious nights in intensive care.A No spokesman said the PM “will receive close monitoring” and was “in extremely good spirits”. The PM’s fiancée Carrie Symonds broke her silence by tweeting multiple clapping hand emojis and a child’s painting of a rainbow, as the country applauded health workers at pm. Government officials are now confident that new coronavirus infections are starting to level off. But as Mr Johnson spent his fth night in hospital, Mr Raab said it was too soon to begin lting the measures brought in almost three weeks ago.  Saying the Government would not even begin re-assessing the lockdown until the end of next week, he urged the public to think “long and hard” about the impact on heroic NHS staffthey ignored the rules. “After all the efforts everybody has made, after all the sacrices so many people have made let’s not ruin it now,” Mr Raab said. “Let’s not undo the gains we’ve made, let’s not waste the sacrices so many people have made. We mustn’t give the coronavirus a second chance to kill more people and to hurt our country.” Apologising that people would not be able to spend time with their families over Easter he added: “The deaths are still rising. It’s too early to lt the measures that we put in place.”  Ministers launched a Stay at Home This Easter publicity drive designed to make sunseekers think twice.And stars from sport, and music backed the message. England and Manchester United footballer Marcus Rashford, and Happy Mondays singer Shaun Ryder joined key workers to record clips for a video released by Greater Manchester Police yesterday.The warnings come as new figures showed the number of hospital patients who have died after testing positive rose  to ,. But the rate of new infections appears to have slowed and officials are confident lockdown is working. Sources say they now believe Brits with Covid- are infecting on average less than one person each. This is the crucial reproduction numberthreshold which,kept up, would see the outbreak die out. New daily confirmed cases fell to , yesterday, a signicant drop from , the previous day. This had been falling with , on Tuesday, , on Monday, down from the peak of , on Sunday. Lockdown began after modelling showed the reproduction number– or amount of people each carrier infects – was between  and ., meaning cases doubling every four or five days.  A source leading the response to the crisis said: “If the R goes below , the epidemic just dies out anyway, which is hopefully what’s happening. “If the R is somewhat above  you can control it with active measures.” Daily testing is now starting to be increased to around , after stalling near the , a day mark. But insiders say easing lockdown can only be consideredthe Government meets its ,-a-day target. Even then it can only happensocial distancing has been maintained and hospitals are well within capacity. But the focus is now moving move to a Government “exit strategy”, which it has repeatedly refused to outline.Labour leader Sir Keir Starmer asked ministers to publish plans to get Britain out of the lockdown.He said: “I’m not calling for timings, but the strategy. We need to know plans are in place, and what they are.” Downing Street said police would have the “full support” of Government in enforcing the coronavirus lockdown at this “critical juncture”.

Dr Ayache was taken by ambulance to Ipswich Hospital on April  where he was diagnosed with bilateral pneumonia and coronavirus and died six days later. I wholeheartedly believe thatsomeone had called him with a concern he would have gone over and checked they were OK, because thataposs what he wanted to do for everybody. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email A mum who stockpiled food at the start of the coronavirus pandemic has been forced to bin piles of rotting food - but still vows to keep stripping shelves.Factory worker Emmie Shute, , has just three mouths to feed, but says the pandemic outbreak in the UK sent her straight to the shops. Emmie splurged a whopping £ on food - much of which was perishable and has now gone off - leaving her with no choice but to dump it. The stockpiling mum says she now spends £ a week on shopping - and throws away around % of what she spends. Despite this, Emmie says she feels no guilt in throwing away food while others maybe going without. She said: I understand the criticism about food not being left for vulnerable people and key workers, but I donapost feel bad - itaposs supermarketsapos responsibility to order more and make sure they have enough stock in. Now, as Easter approaches, single mum Emmie said she will continue to stockpile, despite numerous heartbreaking stories of the elderly and the most vulnerable being left without any food.  Emmie said she plans on buying more chocolate, biscuits and treats for her three children because now more than ever she wants to spoil them. Speaking about her hoarding , Emmie said she was terried at what was to come, so packed her fridge with groceries, including lots of fruit, veg, biscuits, eggs, tinned food, pasta and  toilet rolls. Emmie revealed however that many of the toilet rolls were also binned as they accidentally got wet from the shower. The mum, speaking to Fabulous magazine, said she felt like she had been plunged into a disaster movie and was forced to think of what her children would and wouldnapost eat during the lockdown.When her children refused to eat some of the food she had stockpiled, Emmie said she needed to make room for things they did like.

The -year-old south Londoner then died last Friday in intensive care.Brother Yasser told the Daily Mail that Ayub, of Norwood, was struggling to breathe and he could hear his painful coughing during the night.For the latest on the coronavirus pandemic, click here Within days of picking up the woman in his Prius he felt cold and couldnapost stop coughing before an ambulance was called when his condition deteriorated. Ayubaposs brother, Yasser, said he developed coronavirus symptoms shortly after picking up the coughing passenger. He was taken to Mayday Hospital in Croydon before being moved to St Georgeaposs Hospital, Tooting, where he messaged his family to tell them he was really scared and to pray for him. His family were unable to be at his bedside when he died a few days later due to how infectious the disease is.  Yasser said they knew he was seriously ill because he would take a day to respond to any messages while in ITU. Doctors were asking him to breathe with his lungs but it became impossible, he added. It has all happened so quick. It destroyed him, he said, holding back tears. Yasser went on to say the family has not seen his brother yet and they donapost know when the funeral will be, with burials usually done within a day or two in their religion. It is believed there are several taxi drivers seriously ill with Covid symptoms. The Chair of United Private Hire Drivers, James Farrar is seeking a Judicial Review to examine whether London Taxi Drivers are properly protected. He is concerned many more may have been infected because of inadequate protection.Ayub and Yasser helped found a local UPHD branch and gave himself to help others and to build our movement for change, according to a Gofundme page set up in his honour.Together with Yasser, he  bravely challenged  the terrible injustices of our industry.  He stood against discrimination, fought to end exploitation and worked tirelessly so that drivers might have a better le. The page has already raised over £, to go towards his memory and to help his family pay for his funeral. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email Prince Harry and Meghan’s new foundation was shaken after an internet troll hacked its website – and linked it to Kanye West ’s “Gold ­Digger” video.The Duke and Duchess of Sussex said this week they were planning to set up the non-profit Archewell Foundation. But fans who visited www.archewellfoundation were redirected to a video of rapper Kanye’s  hit. As of yesterday anyone typing in the address got a message saying, “This site can’t be reached”, after internet hosts took action. But many viewers had already given their verdict.  One wrote beneath the song on YouTube: “Hahahah, whoever did this on Meghan and Harry’s website is a genius.”And a Twitter user called Violet added: “Meghan and Harry leave the UK to raise their son in privacy.No, we aren’t going to launch a foundation. Two weeks later they announce Archewell Foundation.  “If you type Archewellfoundation YouTube plays Golddigger. Hilarious.” Kanye is no stranger to such pranks. He was targeted in  by a troll who made website loser redirect visitors to his Wikipedia entry. On Tuesday, the Duke and Duchess announced from their LA home they were launching Archewell and its links with their son’s name. They had to scrap their SussexRoyal brand after the Queen reportedly banned them using royal ties to make money. In a statement, Harry, , and Meghan, , said: “Like you, our focus is on supporting efforts to tackle the global Covid- pandemic. “But faced with this information coming to light, we felt compelled to share the story of how this came to be.

title: new york now burying coronavirus
story: NewsNew York now burying coronavirus victims in mass graves with more cases than any countryThe victims of coronavirus in New York, which has been ravaged by the outbreak, have been buried in mass graves on Hart Island, off the Bronx, which has been used to bury poor people for  yearsShareCommentsByMilo Boyd:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsDrone pictures show bodies being buried on New Yorks Hart Island " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe victims of Covid- in New York have been buried in mass graves as the city struggles to cope with the coronavirus. Shocking images taken from a drone show workers using ladders to climb into a huge pit on Hart Island, off the Bronx. The area has been used for mass burials for those who have no next-of-kin, or whose families canapost afford funerals, for the past  years. Typically, some  bodies are interred each week by low-paid jail inmates working on the island, which is accessible only by boat. Do you have a coronavirus story  Email webnews@trinitymirror That number began increasing in March as the new coronavirus spread rapidly, making New York the epicentre of the global pandemic. New York state now has more coronavirus cases than any other country outside the US, after a jump of , on Thursday to nearly , put it ahead of Spain and Italy. The stateaposs death toll is similar to the UKaposs, with more than , fatalities among a US-wide number of more than ,. For context, New York stateaposs population is just under a third of that of the UK at about  million. There are about two dozen bodies a day, five days a week buried on the island, said Jason Kersten, a spokesman for the Department of Correction, which oversees the burials. Before burial, the dead are wrapped in body bags and placed inside pine caskets. The deceasedaposs name is scrawled in large letters on each casket, which helps should a body need to be disinterred later.  They are buried in long narrow trenches excavated by digging machines.  They added two new trenches in case we need them, Mr Kersten said. To help with the surge contract laborers have been hired, he said. For social distancing and safety reasons, city-sentenced people in custody are not assisting in burials for the duration of the pandemic, Mr Kersten said. A barge could be seen arriving at the island on Thursday morning with a refrigerated truck aboard containing about two dozen bodies.  The department referred questions about causes of death to the cityaposs Office of the Chief Medical Examiner . The island may also be used as a site for temporary interments should deaths surge past the cityaposs morgue capacity, a point that has not yet been reached, Mr Kersten said. U.S. deaths due to coronavirus topped , on Thursday, according to a Reuters tally, although there are signs the outbreak might be nearing a peak.  U.S. officials warned Americans to expect alarming numbers of coronavirus deaths this week, even as there was evidence that the number of new infections was flattening in New York state, the epicenter of the U.S. outbreak.
